head.title: Costs for Ballpark Rise by $1 Million

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Costs for Ballpark Rise by $1 Million

abstract.p: Price for new minor league ball park now under construction by Suffolk County in Central Islip has risen by million dollars, to meet higher-than-expected building material costs; county will lease 6,000-seat ballpark to Long Island Ducks of Atlantic League (S)

block.p: The price for the new minor league ball park now under construction by Suffolk County in Central Islip has risen by a million dollars.

The additional money, which county Public Works Commissioner Charles Bartha said was needed to meet higher-than-expected building material costs, brought the cost to nearly $20 million. The amount includes a state grant of $14.4 million.
The price for the new minor league ball park now under construction by Suffolk County in Central Islip has risen by a million dollars.

The additional money, which county Public Works Commissioner Charles Bartha said was needed to meet higher-than-expected building material costs, brought the cost to nearly $20 million. The amount includes a state grant of $14.4 million.

The county will lease the 6,000-seat ballpark to the Long Island Ducks of the Atlantic League and expects to cover its $5.5 million investment in rent, ticket surcharges and other revenues. Opening day is April 28.
Mr. Bartha said the lease was still being negotiated.
County legislators approved the additional spending in a 12-to-5 vote late last month, but some legislators are flashing anxious signals.

Legislator Michael Caracciolo, a Republican from Riverhead, said the lease needed close scrutiny. He said he wanted team owners to invest in the ballpark project and perhaps share in the higher material costs.
Other legislators chastised Mr. Bartha for not keeping them informed about project costs and pinned their support for the $1 million increase to assurances that they would be kept better informed.
